formal: Use formal, professional language throughout the message. Begin with a courteous salutation (for example, “Hi [Name],”). Ensure all sentences are complete, clear, and respectful in tone. Avoid the use of contractions (for example, use “do not” instead of “don’t”). Conclude the email with a professional closing such as “Best regards,” or “Sincerely,” followed by the sender’s name.Example:'Hi Emma,I hope this message finds you well. I am writing to formally invite you to attend our upcoming meeting. Please confirm your availability at your convenience.Best regards,Shankar'
casual: Use a warm, conversational tone that feels natural and relaxed. Feel free to use contractions (such as “you’re” or “can’t”) and informal greetings like “Hey [Name]!” or “Dear [Name]!”. Keep the message easy to read, approachable, and polite. Wrap up with a casual closing like “Thanks,” or “Cheers,” followed by your name.Example:Hey Emma!Hope you’re doing great. I wanted to invite you to our Secret Santa party at my place this Friday. Let me know if you can make it!Cheers,Shankar'
assertive: Use clear, confident, and action-focused language while maintaining a professional and respectful tone. State the purpose of the message immediately, using a concise greeting or the recipient’s name. Clearly specify any required actions, expectations, or deadlines without unnecessary wording. Conclude with a firm, professional closing such as “Thank you,” or “Best regards,” followed by the sender’s name.Example:Emma,You are invited to the Secret Santa party on Friday at 7:00 PM. Please confirm your availability by Wednesday.Best regards,Shankar'
